conclusion: To determine the average velocities of both cars, we need to analyze the velocity-time graph provided.
The given graph shows the velocity (v) on the y-axis against time (t) on the x-axis for two cars, A and B.
v1 and v2 represent the initial and final velocities respectively for each car.
The point where the velocity lines of A and B intersect gives us the instant when they have the same speed.
The average velocity (v_avg) over an interval can be calculated using the formula: v_avg = total displacement / total time.
For uniform motion, this simplifies to the arithmetic mean of the initial and final velocities.
Since the cars do not move with constant velocities, we use the area under the velocity-time curve as a more accurate method to find the average velocity.

premise: The area under the curve represents the total displacement.
conclusion: For Car A, the area is bounded by the line A from v2 to v1 and the horizontal axis.

premise: The area under the curve represents the total displacement.
conclusion: For Car B, the area is bounded by the line B from v1 to v2 and the horizontal axis.

premise: The areas under the curves for both cars are effectively the same (as they are both half of a similar bounding rectangle).
conclusion: The average velocities will be equal.

premise: The average speed of A is greater than the speed of the red line throughout the entire journey, so the average speed of A is greater than that of the red line. The situation for B is completely opposite.
conclusion: The average speed of A is greater than that of B.
